intro: Rupalleya volubilis, commonly known as the climbing bellflower, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It is a member of the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its trailing growth habit and showy, bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically produces blue or purple flowers that bloom in late summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Its stems are covered in fine hairs, and it thrives in well-drained, rocky soils at high altitudes. Rupalleya volubilis is often found in alpine meadows and is adapted to cold, harsh environments.
